Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Variational Inequalities: Analysis, Computation, and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stochastic variational inequalities model a large number of equilibrium problems subject to data uncertainty. They are closely related to stochastic optimization problems, which form an important subfield of mathematical optimization. The investigator and her colleagues study the mathematical structure of stochastic variational inequalities, develop their solution methods and analytic tools, and apply these to handle data uncertainty in equilibrium and optimization problems. They analyze the relation between parameters and solutions of stochastic variational inequalities, investigate the convergence of major computational methods such as the sample average approximation method, and use such knowledge to develop and justify methods to establish confidence regions for solutions to stochastic variational inequalities and stochastic optimization problems. To broaden the application areas of these methods, they extend the work from single-stage problems to multi-stage ones, and from the single measure of expected values to a general class of risk measures. They implement the resulting computational tools in specific operational planning problems.

The variational inequality is a mathematical problem that characterizes an equilibrium status. It provides a unified framework for a very large number of problems from areas including materials science, transportation, computer networks, signal processing, mechanics, economics, and other areas. Whereas deterministic variational inequalities are formulated with fixed parameters, real world problems almost invariably include some uncertain parameters. Such uncertainty may be caused by lack of reliable data, measurement errors, future and unobservable events, and so on. A common approach to tackling such uncertainty is by introducing a probability distribution on the parameters. The resulting problem is a stochastic variational inequality, which aims to find the "average" equilibrium status. Stochastic variational inequalities have been used to model a wide variety of problems in energy market analysis, communication network modeling, transportation planning, inventory management, and other areas. In this research, the investigator and her colleagues study to develop better insight into the mathematical structure of stochastic variational inequalities, and to exploit this insight to produce better computational algorithms and analytic tools. They investigate how solutions to these problems depend on their data, how to find a good solution effectively, and how to identify practical problems that are easy to solve and have robust behavior. Success in the work helps to better understand, analyze and solve a broad class of equilibrium and optimization problems subject to data uncertainty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stochastic variational inequalities model a large number of equilibrium and optimization problems subject to data uncertainty. Such problems arise from areas such as economics, engineering and statistics. In those problems, the true values of certain data (such as parameters in the supply and demand functions of a product) are unknown, and sample averages are used to approximate the true values. The approximating problems are then solved numerically. A question of fundamental interest is whether a solution obtained for the approximating problem, called an SAA solution, is a reliable estimate for a true solution. The goal of this project is to answer this question through construction of confidence regions and confidence intervals for the true solution. 

By combining sensitivity analysis techniques developed for variational inequalities with probability theory, we obtain an expression for the asymptotic distribution of the SAA solutions. The nonsmooth structure of variational inequalities is reflected in the discontinuity of certain quantities in the asymptotic distribution, which prevents the applicability of standard techniques for constructing confidence regions. We overcome this challenge by exploiting the precise geometric structure of variational inequalities and establishing weak convergence theorems tailored to account for the piecewise structure. This enables us to provide the first methods to build asymptotically exact confidence regions and confidence intervals for true solutions to stochastic variational inequalities, for the general situation in which the asymptotic distribution is not necessarily normal. Computation of confidence regions using our method is surprisingly efficient, even when the asymptotic distribution consists of multiple pieces. Computation of individual confidence intervals is more complicated in those situations, and we propose a conditioning approach to reduce the amount of computation to a single piece in the piecewise linear structure, to improve the computation efficiency for those situations.

We have applied our methods in the area of statistical learning. We have proposed new methods for conducting inference for the LASSO, a common method for linear regression, as well as general sparse penalized statistical regression such as MCP and SCAD. 

Our work on stochastic variational inequalities provides a rigorous approach to analyzing solution reliability for a broad class of equilibrium and optimization problems with uncertain data. It also provides an excellent opportunity for interdisciplinary research between optimization, statistics and probability theory.
